perturbation.original_text:
10.4 Payment of Invoices

Each invoice provided by Supplier to Customer under Section 10.1, to the extent accurate, shall be paid by Customer to Supplier within [* * *] after the date of the invoice to the extent that Customer does not reasonably dispute that portion of the invoice in good faith.

All payments will be made in U.S. Dollars by SWIFT bank transfer directly to the Supplier account as specified in the respective Purchase Orders.
perturbation.changed_text:
10.4 Payment of Invoices

Each invoice provided by Supplier to Customer under Section 10.1, to the extent accurate, shall be paid by Customer to Supplier within [* * *] after the date of the invoice. However, if the Customer believes the invoice to be inaccurate, they have [* * *] to file a dispute.

All payments will be made in U.S. Dollars by SWIFT bank transfer directly to the Supplier account as specified in the respective Purchase Orders.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a contradiction by stating that invoices must be paid within [* * *] while also allowing for a [* * *] dispute period. This creates uncertainty in enforcement as it is not clear whether the Customer can withhold payment during the dispute period and what the repercussions are.

perturbation.original_text:
8.1 Acceptance of Shipments

Customer or its designees shall, within a period of [* * *] after the date of physical receipt of any shipment of Product from Supplier, inspect the Product for any shortages or any defects or deviations of the Product   CONFIDENTIAL  Page 23 of 49

Source: PARATEK PHARMACEUTICALS, INC., 10-K/A, 5/5/2017

Specifications (hereinafter "Out Of Specification") that would be apparent from visual inspections of the Product. In the event that Customer is of the opinion that the Product is Out Of Specification at the time of delivery, Customer shall, within [* * *] after the date of physical receipt of Product, provide Supplier with a written notice to reject the Product (a "Notice of Rejection"), which shall include a description of the grounds for rejection and copies of test reports and testing methodology conducted on the Product, if any. However, with respect to any Out Of Specification Product which would not be apparent from a reasonable visual inspection on delivery, including in the case of any hidden defects, such Notice of Rejection shall be provided to Supplier not later than [* * *].
perturbation.changed_text:
8.1 Acceptance of Shipments

Customer or its designees shall, within a period of [* * *] after the date of physical receipt of any shipment of Product from Supplier, inspect the Product for any shortages or any defects or deviations of the Product   CONFIDENTIAL  Page 23 of 49

Source: PARATEK PHARMACEUTICALS, INC., 10-K/A, 5/5/2017

Specifications (hereinafter "Out Of Specification") that would be apparent from visual inspections of the Product. In the event that Customer is of the opinion that the Product is Out Of Specification at the time of delivery, Customer shall, within [* * *] after the date of physical receipt of Product, provide Supplier with a written notice to reject the Product (a "Notice of Rejection"), which shall include a description of the grounds for rejection and copies of test reports and testing methodology conducted on the Product, if any. However, with respect to any Out Of Specification Product which would not be apparent from a reasonable visual inspection on delivery, including in the case of any hidden defects, such Notice of Rejection shall be provided to Supplier no later than [* * *], unless the defect is deemed a 'critical defect' in which case, Customer has until [* * *] to provide Supplier with a written notice of rejection.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a contradiction by establishing a general deadline of [* * *] for hidden defects, while simultaneously introducing a separate, longer deadline of [* * *] for 'critical defects.' This creates an ambiguity in the enforcement and application of the inspection/rejection clauses.

The change introduces an inconsistency by stating termination under section 18.1(a) is effective immediately, while the original text specified it would be effective as of the expiration date of the Initial Term. This creates ambiguity about when the termination takes effect and adds potential for dispute.
